example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 3, Ms. Elena Petrova, 47 years old. She’s been admitted for major depressive disorder and has been on amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, for the past two weeks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. What’s happening currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s developed an oculogyric crisis—her eyes are rolling upward involuntarily, and she’s visibly distressed. It started about an hour ago. She’s aware of it and frightened, but still orientated and able to speak.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has medical been notified?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, the on-call doctor has reviewed her. They suspect it’s a dystonic reaction to the tricyclics. IM benztropine 2 mg has been charted and given about 20 minutes ago. We’re monitoring for response.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other symptoms?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No limb dystonia or airway involvement. Her Vitals are stable, She’s anxious but cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she’s from a non-English speaking background—Russian is her first language. She understands basic English but struggles with medical terms. Interpreter has been requested for tomorrow’s review. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on: Amitriptyline 75 mg nocte, Diazepam 5 mg PRN, Paracetamol PRN. There is No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring her response to benztropine and keep her calm.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if the symptoms persist or worsen. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, I need to escalate a concern about Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, currently in bed 5 on the urology ward. He’s been deteriorating clinically — I’m not exactly sure what’s triggering it, but I think he needs a medical review soon, possibly urgently.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, what’s going on?
[NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday with acute urinary retention and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. A catheter was inserted last night, but over the last few hours he seems to have become more lethargic, tachycardic, and hypotensive. His urine output’s dropped quite a bit — not sure if the catheter’s blocked or if he’s just shutting down.
[DOCTOR]: What are his current vitals?
[NURSE]: BP’s sitting around 88/54, HR about 112, RR 22, SpO₂ 96% on room air, temp 37.9°C. He’s only passed about 40 mL in the last three hours, give or take. His Q‑ADDS is around 7, though I’ll double‑check — it might be 8 depending on the scoring for output.
[DOCTOR]: Any pain or other symptoms?
[NURSE]: He’s got some lower abdominal discomfort — says it’s “tight” more than painful — and a low‑grade fever. He’s a bit confused, which the team on shift earlier didn’t mention, so that’s new. No vomiting that I’ve seen, but he’s refusing fluids and looks a little clammy.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, this morning’s labs: white cell 14.6, CRP 98, creatinine 168 from 102 yesterday, eGFR down to 44 — sorry, I think it’s 44, not 4, but I can confirm. Looks like he might be heading into an acute kidney injury, possibly secondary to infection, obstruction, or both. Micro hasn’t come back yet, but urine looked cloudy.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, thanks. I’ll come and review him now — give me about ten minutes. We may need imaging and probably to escalate to the surgical team if obstruction’s worsening. I’ll decide once I’ve seen him.
[NURSE]: Alright, I’ll keep an eye on him for now and prepare in case you want to transfer or escalate further.

example.text:
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Good morning, Ms. Lopez. I’m Dr. Chen from City Surgical Unit. I’ll get handover from my colleague now, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: This is bed 5, Maria Lopez, 46 years old, under Dr. Singh.
She was admitted yesterday with acute right upper quadrant pain and nausea. An Ultrasound confirmed multiple gallstones with signs of cholecystitis. She’s being transferred for laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: She’s hemodynamically stable. No signs of biliary obstruction. Her pain is controlled with regular analgesia. There have been no changes in her condition overnight. 
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Hi Ms. Lopez, can you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Maria Lopez.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Thank you. I’ll also check your wristband. That matches.
Are you experiencing any pain or discomfort right now?
[PATIENT]: Just a little soreness, but it’s better than yesterday.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Vital signs this morning is BP: 124/76, HR: 82 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 37.2
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[PATIENT]: None that I know of.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: I’ll confirm that in the chart.
What’s her current medication chart?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]:
She’s currently receiving: IV ceftriaxone 1g daily for suspected cholecystitis, IV metronidazole 500mg TDS, Paracetamol 1g QID orally, Ondansetron 4mg IV PRN for nausea, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr and has been NBM since admission
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any relevant past medical history?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes: Hypertension (on amlodipine 5mg daily), No diabetes, No previous surgeries, No known liver disease
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: So, the plan is transfer her for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. No outstanding investigations?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]:  Bloods from yesterday: WCC: 11.2, CRP: 45, LFTs: mildly elevated ALT 68, ALP 110, bilirubin is normal, Renal function is normal, her Electrolytes are within range.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]:  Ms. Lopez, is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Alright, I’ll see you again shortly once you’re settled in.

[RECOVERY_NURSE]:
Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, transferring to your ward post-procedure. He had a urethral dilation and bladder washout under general anaesthetic due to acute urinary retention and suspected obstructive uropathy.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: It went smoothly. No complications in theatre. He’s now stable but needs close monitoring due to recent deterioration pre-op—he was hypotensive and oliguric. He’s now passing urine via IDC, and output is improving.
[WARD_NURSE]: Vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: BP: 112/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 37.4°C, Urine output: 120 mL in the last hour
[WARD_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes: he has an IDC draining with clear urine, an IV cannula in left forearm, there are No infusions running currently and Oxygen via nasal prongs earlier, now weaned off
[WARD_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, Gentamicin IV stat dose given in theatre, PRN oxycodone and IV fluids were running intra-op, now ceased.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes, he’s from a Vietnamese-speaking background and has limited English. Interpreter has been requested for ward rounds. His son is bilingual and will be visiting later today.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. Any outstanding tasks?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s due for post-op obs in 30 minutes, and the IDC needs to be monitored closely. Urology team will review later today. He’s alert but tired.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll get him settled and continue monitoring.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Great. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Singh, I need to escalate a concern about Mrs. Joan Wallace, bed 7. She’s Day 5 post-abdominal surgery and was awaiting PEG insertion, but she’s now showing signs of clinical deterioration.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, what’s happening?
[NURSE]: She’s become increasingly hypotensive and tachycardic, and her respiratory rate is elevated. She’s also confused, which is new. Her urine output has dropped, and she’s looking pale and clammy.
[DOCTOR]: Do you have her latest vitals?
[NURSE]: Yes: BP: 86/52, HR: 118 bpm, RR: 26, SpO?: 94% on 4L nasal prongs, Temp: 38.2°C, Urine output: 30 mL over the last 3 hours and Q-ADDS score: 8
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, from this morning her WCC: 15.4, CRP: 122, Creatinine: 168, Lactate: 3.1
She’s likely heading into sepsis or acute kidney injury.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll come and review her immediately. We may need to escalate to ICU for closer monitoring and support.
[NURSE]: Understood. I’ll prepare for potential transfer and notify the bed manager.
[NURSE (to BED MANAGER)]: Hi, I’m calling regarding Mrs. Joan Wallace, bed 7. She’s deteriorating post-abdominal surgery and may require ICU admission. The doctor is reviewing her now, but I wanted to flag the need for a potential ICU bed.
[BED MANAGER]: Thanks for the heads-up. I’ll check availability and hold a bed provisionally. Please confirm once the doctor makes the decision.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll keep you updated.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, thanks for coming. I’d like you to review Ms. Evelyn Grant in bed 9. She’s a 68-year-old admitted with a urinary tract infection, now deteriorating—likely urosepsis.
[DOCTOR]: What’s happening?
[NURSE]: Over the past few hours, she’s become increasingly tachycardic and febrile. Her Q-ADDS score is 6, which triggered escalation. She’s also more confused than her baseline—normally oriented but now disoriented to time and place.
[DOCTOR]: Can you give me her latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 98/62, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.6°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, Conscious state: Alert but confused, Q-ADDS score: 6 (HR + Temp + RR + confusion)
[DOCTOR]: Has she had any recent bloods or cultures?
[NURSE]: Yes. Bloods were taken this morning: WCC: 14.2, CRP: 98, Creatinine: 102 (baseline ~85) Urine sample: Sent, we are waiting results Lactate: Not yet done—would you like it ordered?
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: No current vascular access. She had a cannula yesterday, but it was removed due to tissuing. I can insert a new one now.
[DOCTOR]: What’s her fluid balance?
[NURSE]: Input (last 24h): ~1200 mL (oral + IV), Output: ~600 mL urine, no vomiting or diarrhoea, Net balance: +600 mL, Urine output: Reduced over last 6 hours—only 100 mL
[DOCTOR]: Allergy status?
[NURSE]: Documented penicillin allergy—rash and swelling previously.
[DOCTOR]: Current medications?
[NURSE]: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr, No antibiotics yet—awaiting review due to allergy
[DOCTOR]: Okay. I’ll assess her now. Let’s insert a cannula, take a lactate, and start IV ceftriaxone and gentamicin. We’ll monitor closely and consider AMU transfer if she worsens.
[NURSE]: I’ll insert the cannula, draw the lactate, and prep the antibiotics. I’ll also notify AMU if her Q-ADDS increases or confusion worsens.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago following a manic episode. She’s now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder and is being discharged today. I’d like to arrange home supports to help her transition safely.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. Can you tell me about her current situation?
[NURSE]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband is supportive but understandably overwhelmed. He’s asked for help managing the household while Emily stabilises. She’s currently well but still adjusting to the diagnosis.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What kind of supports do you think she’ll need?
[NURSE]: She’ll benefit from: Domestic assistance (light cleaning, laundry, meal prep), Childcare support during the day, especially for the younger children, Mental health outreach for medication adherence and mood monitoring, Education for the family around bipolar disorder and crisis planning. Possibly pet care support if her condition fluctuates
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Any safety concerns?
[NURSE]: No current risks identified. She’s engaging well, has insight, and is compliant with treatment. Her husband is aware of early warning signs and has contact details for crisis support.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What’s her medication plan?
[NURSE]:
She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg – not used in the last 48 hours, she’ll need regular lithium level monitoring and follow-up with the community mental health team.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. I’ll organise a home support package and liaise with the mental health team and family services.
[NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything further from the ward team.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. James Nolan in bed 4. He’s a 67-year-old patient admitted overnight with a suspected small bowel obstruction. He’s been reviewed by the surgical team and is currently awaiting theatre—likely this afternoon.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What are his current symptoms?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s had abdominal distension, nausea, and vomiting since yesterday. No bowel movements for 48 hours. He’s nil by mouth and has an NG tube on free drainage, which has drained about 400 mL of bilious fluid since insertion.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s his current status?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Vitals are stable: BP: 128/76, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, Temp: 37.2°C, SpO?: 97% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 3 (based on nausea, pain, and reduced output)
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his right forearm—patent. He’s on IV Normal Saline at 125 mL/hr. Electrolytes are being monitored—latest bloods show mild hypokalaemia (K+ 3.2), so we’ve added potassium to his fluids.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s charted for: IV Metoclopramide 10 mg TDS, IV Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Morphine 2.5–5 mg SC for pain, Nil oral meds due to NBM status
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure care or hygiene needs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s been in bed most of the shift. We’ve started 2-hourly repositioning and he’s on a pressure-relieving mattress. No current pressure injuries. He’ll need a full wash this morning and assistance with hygiene.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and prep him for theatre.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, I’m the incoming nurse for bed 4 my name is Peter. I’ll get handover from you now, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is bed 4, Mr. Daniel Reid, mid-50s, admitted yesterday under Dr. Kumar with a Non-ST Elevation MI, confirmed as a posterior infarct on ECG and troponins.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s currently tachycardic—HR around 108—and hypotensive, BP sitting around 92/58. He’s being monitored closely. Oxygen saturations are stable at 96% on room air. His Q-ADDS score is 7, mainly due to HR, BP, and altered behaviour.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Is he scheduled for any procedures?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, he’s booked for an angiogram later today. He’s NBM and awaiting transfer to cath lab. No IV access at present—needs a cannula inserted pre-procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, he has a documented allergy to penicillin—rash and swelling reported previously.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his current medication chart?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on: Aspirin 300 mg stat, then 100 mg daily, Ticagrelor 90 mg BD, Atorvastatin 80 mg nocte, IV fluids: Normal saline at 80 mL/hr, PRN paracetamol, No opioids charted due to substance use history.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any relevant medical history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, Chronic back pain, Hypertension, No diabetes, No prior cardiac events, Regular cannabis use for pain, now withdrawing—he’s been restless, loud, and disruptive overnight. Behavioural charting is in place. He’s aware of the situation but fluctuates in his engagement with us. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has Drug and Alcohol been consulted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: A Referral was sent this morning—awaiting review. He may need transfer to a higher acuity ward if behaviour escalates or vitals worsen.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll insert the cannula and keep a close eye on his vitals and behaviour. I’ll follow up with the Drug and Alcohol team as well.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything. He’s currently resting but may become noisy again.

[NURSE 2]: Got it. Anything else I need to follow up?

[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over details for Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky at home.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[NURSE]: He’s currently drowsy but rousable, with slurred speech and intermittent agitation. He’s on 2 L/min oxygen via nasal prongs, with SpO? around 92%. GCS is 13. He’s under close observation and has IV access in place.
[PHARMACIST]: Have any treatments been initiated?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’ve started IV fluids (Normal Saline) and taken bloods for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. We’re awaiting results to determine if N-acetylcysteine is required. No activated charcoal was given due to delayed presentation and reduced consciousness.
[PHARMACIST]: Any known allergies or regular medications?
[NURSE]: No known drug allergies. No regular medications documented at this stage. He’s a daily smoker and reports high alcohol intake.
[PHARMACIST]: Any concerns about interactions or toxicity?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’re concerned about hepatotoxicity from paracetamol, sedation from Serepax, and CNS depression from alcohol. He’s being monitored for respiratory compromise and liver function deterioration.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. I’ll review his chart and prepare for possible NAC administration. Let me know once the blood results are back.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll keep you updated on his clinical status and any changes.

[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED earlier today following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky after a fight with his partner.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He’s currently drowsy but rousable, with slurred speech, intermittent agitation, and low oxygen saturations—around 92% on 2 L nasal prongs. GCS is 13. He’s under close observation and has IV access in place. Bloods have been taken for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. We’re awaiting results to determine if NAC is required.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Any known substance use history?
[ED Nurse]: He’s a daily smoker and reports heavy alcohol use, especially during periods of stress. No documented history of drug use, but this is his first known overdose. He’s not currently linked in with any mental health or addiction services.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Any social concerns?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he lives with his partner, and the overdose occurred following a verbal altercation. He’s currently not safe to discharge and will need a mental health review once medically stable. No children at home, but he’s expressed feelings of hopelessness and anger.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll assess him once he’s more alert and begin planning for support post-discharge, including possible referral to AOD services and counselling.
[ED Nurse]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything from the medical team or if you’d like to join the MDT review later today.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Kyle Jensen in bed 3. He’s a 29-year-old male admitted through ED last night following a stab wound to the left lower abdomen. He’s currently stable but requires ongoing wound care and IV medications.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current status of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: The wound is approximately 4 cm in length, deep but not penetrating any major organs. It was cleaned and sutured in ED. There’s mild swelling and bruising around the site, but no signs of active bleeding or infection. Dressing is intact and due for review this afternoon.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any neurovascular concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Neurovascular obs are normal his Sensation and movement in lower limbs are intact, the Capillary refill less than 2 seconds, and there are No signs of vascular compromise.
[Incoming Nurse]: What medications is he on?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s currently on: IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily, IV Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Morphine 2.5–5 mg SC for pain he has No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other monitoring?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: a Fluid Balance Chart: Input ~1200 mL, Output ~900 mL (urine via voiding), he has a Q-ADDS score: Currently 3 (due to pain and elevated HR) His vitals are stable. 
[Incoming Nurse]: Any psychosocial concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s cooperative but anxious. Police have been notified due to the nature of the injury. No visitors currently. Social work referral has been made.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue wound care, monitor his IV therapy, and update his charts.

[NURSE]: Good morning, Dr. Chen. I’d like to hand over Mr. Robert Hayes in bed 12. He’s a 72-year-old patient with congestive heart failure, admitted three days ago with worsening dyspnoea and peripheral oedema. His ejection fraction is 30%, confirmed on echo.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Mr. Hayes, how are you feeling this morning?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit short of breath, especially when I move around. My legs feel heavy.
[NURSE]: He’s been on IV frusemide 40 mg BD, and we’ve seen some improvement in his fluid balance. His Input (last 24h) is  1200 mL his Output is  1800 mL via IDC. His total balance is -600 mL. He’s on a fluid restriction of 1.5 L/day and a low-sodium diet.
[DOCTOR]: Any changes in observations?
[NURSE]: Yes, latest obs: BP: 110/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 20, SpO?: 94% on room air, Temp: 36.7°C and a Q-ADDS score:  of 4 (due to RR and ongoing symptoms). He’s been repositioned 2-hourly, and we’re maintaining pressure area care with a pressure-relieving mattress. No skin breakdown noted.
[DOCTOR]: Any concerns with medications or tolerance?
[NURSE]: He’s tolerating oral meds well he has No known drug allergies.
[PATIENT]: Doctor, do you think I’ll be going home soon?
[DOCTOR]: We’re seeing good progress, Mr. Hayes. We’ll continue monitoring your fluid status and symptoms. If things keep improving, we’ll start planning for discharge with community follow-up.
[NURSE]: I’ll continue monitoring his Q-ADDS, fluid balance, and skin integrity. Would you like a repeat blood panel today?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, let’s check renal function and electrolytes again. Thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Taylor. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Olivia Taylor.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Olivia Taylor in Bed 7, Room 15, aged 38, under Dr. Chen, Emergency Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor presented to ED last night following an assault at home by her intoxicated husband. She has bruising to her left eye and forearm, and a minor laceration to her scalp, which has been cleaned and dressed. CT head was clear. Vitals stable overnight. She’s alert and oriented.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor disclosed that her children are currently at school and she is concerned for their safety. She has not returned home and is unsure of her next steps.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Just sore and tired. I’m worried about my kids.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Understandably. Pain score was 5/10 earlier. She’s had oral analgesia and is tolerating fluids. No nausea or vomiting. A social worker was contacted and will be attending shortly to support safety planning and discuss options.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Olivia, I’m Sarah, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’ve had a very difficult night. I’m here to support you. Would it be okay if we talked for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s okay.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. First, I want to check—are you feeling safe right now? Is your husband aware you’re here?
[PATIENT]: No, he was drunk and passed out when I left. I don’t think he knows.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Okay. We can help ensure your safety while you're here and support you with options for accommodation, legal advice, and child protection if needed. Would you like us to contact someone on your behalf—family, a friend, or a support service?
[PATIENT]: Maybe my sister. She’s in Brisbane.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Absolutely. I’ll help you with that. We’ll also work with the team to make sure your children are safe and supported. You're not alone in this.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Bennett is currently receiving cycle 3 of chemotherapy for breast cancer. She’s had mild nausea overnight, managed with antiemetics. Her vitals are stable, and she’s tolerating oral fluids. Bloods were taken this morning for routine monitoring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s expressed feeling emotionally overwhelmed and worried about managing work and home responsibilities during treatment. A social worker referral was made, and they’re scheduled to visit later this morning.

[PATIENT]: I’m a single mum, and I’ve had to take time off work. I’m worried about bills and keeping things stable for my daughter.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s completely understandable. We can explore options for financial support, community services, and counselling. I can also help connect you with support groups for women going through similar experiences. Would that be helpful?

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Davies. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Davies. This is Emma the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Michael Davies.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. And your date of birth? [PATIENT]: First July 1985. [OUTGOING_NURSE]: And your URN on the armband is 231879, which is what I have on the chart. So, Mr. Davies is under Dr. Kumar from Infectious Diseases — who I think will be the consultant covering this week. Mr. Davies was admitted yesterday with what seems to be acute gastroenteritis, most likely secondary to rotavirus infection. He’s currently being barrier nursed in isolation. Full PPE is required before entering — though I think they were short on gowns earlier, so check the supply trolley just in case. He’s on contact precautions, given the transmission risk.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had several episodes of diarrhoea overnight — not sure how many. Managed with oral rehydration and IV fluids. No vomiting that I’m aware of. Stool sample was sent and the initial report suggests rotavirus, but the full panel isn’t back yet.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s tolerating small sips of water and bits of dry toast this morning. No abdominal pain reported, though he mentioned feeling “a little off” earlier. Continence aids are in use, and environmental services were notified for enhanced cleaning last night, but I’m not completely sure if they’ve been through yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Davies, how are you feeling this morning? Any nausea or cramping?
[PATIENT]: A bit tired, but no pain. Just still needing the bathroom a lot.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay, thanks. He’s aware of the need to remain in isolation and has mostly been cooperative with infection control steps. No visitors allowed at this stage, though I think his partner’s been trying to contact the ward. Dr. Kumar should be reviewing later today — I’m not sure of the exact time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. I’ll keep monitoring his fluids, stool frequency, and general symptoms, and check in again after the review. If there’s any issue with supplies or isolation process, I’ll raise it with infection control.
[PATIENT]: No problem.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mr. Davies. Please use your call bell if you need anything. I’ll be finishing up my shift shortly.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, I’ll be back soon to recheck your obs and update your chart.

[PATIENT]: No, I’m good.

example.text:
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Good morning, Mr. Carter. I’m Dr. Chen from City Thoracic Unit. I’ll just get the handover from my colleague now, if that’s alright.
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: This should be Bed 5, James Carter, 62 years old, under Dr. Singh — I believe he’s the thoracic surgeon on today’s roster. Mr. Carter was admitted yesterday after referral from oncology for surgical review of what appears to be a left upper lobe non-small cell lung carcinoma. He’s had increasing shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month — he’s not sure exactly when it started worsening. CT chest shows a 3.8 cm lesion with no definite mediastinal involvement, but margins are still being reviewed. The PET from last week shows localized uptake, though I think pathology hasn’t correlated all the findings yet.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: He’s currently haemodynamically stable. No haemoptysis or chest pain reported overnight. Oxygen sats are sitting around 96% on room air. Pain’s been manageable with regular paracetamol. No major changes overnight, though he mentioned feeling “a bit tighter” this morning.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Hi Mr. Carter, can I just confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: James Carter.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Great, and I’ll check your wristband… that matches. Are you having any pain or discomfort at the moment?
[PATIENT]: Just some chest tightness, not bad though.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Vitals this morning roughly BP 132/78, HR 76, RR 18, Temp 36.9, SpO₂ 96%. I’ll double‑check the printed obs to be sure.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[PATIENT]: No known allergies.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Okay, I’ll confirm that in the chart. What about current medications?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: He’s on regular paracetamol one gram QID, salbutamol inhaler as needed, pantoprazole 40 daily. No antibiotics at present — there was some discussion yesterday about prophylaxis, but decision pending surgical review. IV fluids were stopped overnight; he’s nil by mouth while waiting for the team to confirm theatre timing, which I think will depend on bed availability and the PFT results.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any relevant medical history?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes — hypertension controlled on amlodipine 5 mg daily, former smoker, about a 30‑pack‑year history, no diabetes that I know of, and no previous thoracic surgery. Oncology mentioned possible mild COPD features, but that hasn’t been formally diagnosed.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: So, plan is MDT review today for potential lobectomy or segmentectomy, is that right?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes, that’s the plan as far as I know. Pulmonary function tests are pending — I think they were booked for this morning, but not entirely sure if they’ve been collected yet. Bloods from yesterday were within normal limits — WCC 7.8, CRP 12, renal and liver fine, ECG normal sinus rhythm. No other outstanding investigations I’m aware of.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Great, thanks. Mr. Carter, anything you need before we wrap up?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Just waiting to find out what’s happening with surgery.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Perfect. We’ll review your results and let you know once the MDT discussion’s finished — should be sometime later today, depending on when the list starts.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Evans. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Evans. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Chloe Evans.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Chloe Evans in Bed 2, Room 10, aged 24, under Dr. Langford, Psychiatry Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Evans was admitted via ED yesterday with concerns of severe restrictive eating behaviour, low BMI, and fatigue. She was brought in by her mother, who reported significant weight loss over the past 3 months and increasing social withdrawal.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s currently on fluid and nutritional monitoring and has been started on a re-feeding protocol under dietitian guidance. Bloods show mild electrolyte imbalance—low phosphate and potassium. ECG showed sinus bradycardia, which is being monitored.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s alert and cooperative but has expressed anxiety around food and body image. A social worker referral has been made to support family involvement and explore outpatient supports post-discharge.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ms. Evans, how are you feeling this morning? Any dizziness or nausea?
[PATIENT]: Just a bit light-headed, but I’m okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had sips of oral nutrition supplement this morning and tolerated it. No vomiting or diarrhoea. Vitals are stable but she remains on daily ECG and bloods. She’s aware of the care plan and has agreed to meet with the mental health team later today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the dietitian and social worker and let the team know when your bloods are back. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Ms. Evans.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Jackson. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Jackson. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: David Jackson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. David Jackson in Bed 4, Room 6, aged 64, under Dr. Patel, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson was admitted two days ago following a left femoral neck fracture sustained at home. He’s awaiting ORIF surgery, which is scheduled for tomorrow morning. He had a fall in the bathroom overnight—he slipped while attempting to mobilise independently.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Post-fall assessment was completed. No new injuries noted. He was reviewed by the medical team and remains hemodynamically stable. Neurovascular status of the affected limb is unchanged. Observations have remained within normal limits.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain is being managed with regular paracetamol and PRN oxycodone. Pain score was 5/10 on movement this morning. He’s currently on bed rest and has been reminded to use the call bell before mobilising. A falls incident report has been completed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Just sore in the hip, but no dizziness.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s tolerating oral intake and has no nausea. No signs of infection. Pre-op bloods and ECG have been completed. Consent for surgery is signed and documented. Physio will review post-op.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the surgical team and ensure falls precautions are in place. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Jackson.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 2, Ms. Leila Haddad, 59 years old. She’s been admitted with a large pericardial effusion—likely secondary to metastatic breast cancer. She’s for pericardiocentesis this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. How is she currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s hemodynamically stable but symptomatic—short of breath at rest, mild chest tightness, and fatigue. No syncope or hypotension. She’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats around 94%.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had an urgent echo showing a large effusion with early signs of tamponade. Cardiology has reviewed and booked her for ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis this afternoon. Consent is done.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—one 18G in the left AC and a 20G in the right forearm. Both patent. She’s on maintenance IV fluids—normal saline at 75 mL/hr.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had IV dexamethasone 8 mg this morning and regular paracetamol for discomfort. PRN midazolam is charted for the procedure. No anticoagulants on board. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Observations?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: BP 102/68, HR 98, RR 22, SpO? 94% on 2 L, Temp 36.8. She’s alert and oriented but anxious. ECG shows low voltage QRS, no arrhythmias.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is her second language—Arabic is her first. She understands most things but prefers slow explanations. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping. Interpreter has been requested for post-procedure education.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring her obs closely and prep her for the drain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if she deteriorates—especially signs of tamponade like hypotension or muffled heart sounds. All documentation is up to date, including consent, obs, and fluid balance.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 8, Mr. Angelo Romano, 84 years old. He’s in for a TAVI via left subclavian access, scheduled for tomorrow morning. He’s now developed a new arrhythmia—I’ve notified the medical team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay—what kind of arrhythmia?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He went into new-onset atrial fibrillation about an hour ago—irregularly irregular rhythm, HR peaked at 130. He’s asymptomatic but more confused than usual. No chest pain or syncope. ECG has been done and uploaded.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The cardiology registrar has been notified and is reviewing. We’ve done a full set of bloods including U&Es, magnesium, and troponin. He’s on telemetry and we’re monitoring closely. No rate control started yet—awaiting medical orders.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his baseline?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Normally in sinus rhythm. He’s got known aortic stenosis and mild cognitive impairment. He’s also incontinent of urine—currently in pads. No IDC.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—18G in the right forearm and 20G in the left hand. Maintenance fluids running at 75 mL/hr. He’s fasting from midnight for the procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Regular meds include frusemide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. No anticoagulants yet—this will likely be reviewed post-TAVI. PRN paracetamol and haloperidol are charted. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his second language—Italian is his first. Interpreter is booked for tomorrow. His daughter is his next of kin and has been very involved. He’s quite anxious and confused, especially with the new arrhythmia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring his rhythm and wait for the plan from cardiology.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if his condition worsens—especially if he becomes hypotensive or more confused. All documentation is up to date, including ECG, fluid balance, and neuro obs.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 3, Mr. David Lee, 79 years old. He had a permanent pacemaker inserted this morning for complete heart block. Post-procedure, he developed a right-sided pneumothorax—a chest drain was inserted about an hour ago.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay—how is he now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s more short of breath and becoming increasingly agitated. His oxygen requirement has gone up—now on 4 L via nasal prongs to maintain sats around 92%. BP is 98/60, HR is 62 (paced), RR 26, Temp 37.2. I’ve escalated to the medical registrar—awaiting review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s the drain functioning?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Swinging but minimal drainage so far. No signs of tension, but I’m concerned about his increased work of breathing and agitation. ECG shows paced rhythm, no acute changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—he’s acutely incontinent of urine and hasn’t voided since the procedure. Abdomen is mildly distended. I’ve requested an IDC insertion—awaiting medical clearance due to the recent pacing procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: One 18G in the left forearm—patent. He’s on maintenance fluids and has had IV paracetamol for discomfort. No antibiotics charted yet. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. He’s usually independent but is now confused and distressed. Family has been notified and are on their way in.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring his respiratory status and follow up on the IDC and medical review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Please escalate if his condition worsens—especially if his sats drop further or he becomes more confused. All documentation is up to date, including drain chart, fluid balance, and neuro obs.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, this is Mrs. Joan Murphy, 73 years old. Joan, this is Liam, one of our physiotherapists. He’s here to help with your breathing and to assist with collecting a sputum sample.
[PHYSIO]: Hi Joan, nice to meet you. I’ll be working with you today to help clear your chest and get a sample if we can. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit chesty and tired. I’ve been coughing but not bringing much up.
[NURSE]: Joan came in last night with an acute exacerbation of COPD—increased SOB, wheeze, and a productive cough. She’s now on IV ceftriaxone and hydrocortisone, and we’re trying to get a sputum sample for culture before the next dose.
[PHYSIO]: Okay, has she been able to expectorate anything yet?
[NURSE]: Not yet—she’s coughing but not clearing much. She’s on salbutamol and ipratropium nebs Q4H, and we’ve just given her a neb about 20 minutes ago to help loosen things up.
[PHYSIO]: Great, that should help. I’ll do some chest physio and see if we can get a sample.
[NURSE]: She’s on 2 L nasal prongs, target sats 88–92%. Her Q-ADDS score is 4, so she’s on 2-hourly observations. RR is 22, sats 91%, HR 96, BP 134/78, Temp 37.4. She’s also on a respiratory chart—we’re tracking sputum colour and volume, and she’s on a fluid balance chart due to poor oral intake.
[PHYSIO]: Understood. Joan, I’ll help you with some breathing techniques and gentle percussion. If you feel the urge to cough anything up, we’ll collect it in a sterile pot.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I’ll try.
[NURSE]: Thanks, Liam. Let me know if you’re able to get a sample or if she needs a second neb beforehand. Everything’s documented in the chart, and the pathology slip is ready.

example.text:
[WARD NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Peter Samuels, 69 years old. He’s being transferred to CCU with acute decompensated heart failure. Peter, this is Nurse Jess from the coronary care unit, and Dr. Patel, who’s overseeing your care.
[CCU NURSE]: Hi Peter, I’ll be looking after you in CCU. We’ll get you settled in and keep a close eye on your breathing and heart.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I’m still feeling short of breath.
[WARD NURSE]: He came in yesterday with worsening dyspnoea, orthopnoea, and peripheral oedema. Chest X-ray showed pulmonary congestion. He’s been started on IV frusemide 40 mg BD, and a GTN infusion was commenced this morning for ongoing hypertension and chest tightness.
[DOCTOR]: We’re titrating the GTN to manage his preload and afterload. He’s also on oxygen via nasal prongs at 4 L/min, aiming for sats above 92%. We’ll review the need for non-invasive ventilation if he doesn’t improve.
[CCU NURSE]: What’s his current status?
[WARD NURSE]: He’s still dyspnoeic at rest. Q-ADDS score is 6—due to increased RR (28), borderline BP (98/60), and oxygen requirement. He’s on hourly observations. HR is 104, Temp 36.8, SpO? 93% on 4 L.
[CCU NURSE]: IV access?
[WARD NURSE]: Two good IVs—18G in the right AC and 20G in the left forearm. GTN is running via pump on the right side. He’s also on a strict fluid balance chart—he’s positive 1.2 L over the last 24 hours. Daily weights are being recorded.
[CCU NURSE]: Any other meds or comorbidities?
[WARD NURSE]: He’s on carvedilol, spironolactone, and atorvastatin. No known allergies. History of ischaemic cardiomyopathy, EF 25%, and CKD stage 3.
[PATIENT]: I’ve been feeling more tired and dizzy today.
[DOCTOR]: That’s why we’re moving you to CCU, Peter—to monitor you more closely and adjust your treatment as needed.
[CCU NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue hourly Q-ADDS, monitor the GTN infusion, and keep a close eye on his fluid status and oxygen needs.
[WARD NURSE]: Perfect. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, fluid balance, and medication chart. Let me know if you need anything else.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Ms. Lily Harper, 24 years old. Lily, this is Nurse Tessa, who’ll be looking after you this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Lily, nice to meet you. I’ll be checking in on you regularly and helping with your care today.
[PATIENT]: Hi. Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Lily was admitted yesterday with bradycardia secondary to an eating disorder—her HR dropped to 38 bpm overnight. She’s now in CCU for cardiac monitoring. She’s alert and oriented but fatigued and intermittently dizzy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s her current status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: HR is sitting around 42–45 bpm, sinus bradycardia on telemetry. BP is 92/58, RR 16, SpO? 98% on room air, Temp 36.2. She’s on Q-ADDS—scoring 5 due to HR and low-normal BP, so we’re doing hourly observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—20G in the left forearm, patent. No IV fluids running currently, but we’ve kept the line in for access if needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on thiamine and multivitamins orally, and PRN lorazepam for anxiety. No cardiac meds charted at this stage. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s her intake?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’ve started a strict food and fluid chart. Dietitian has reviewed and started a re-feeding plan—small, frequent meals. She’s eating slowly but has managed about 50% of her breakfast and lunch today. We’re monitoring for refeeding syndrome—daily bloods are being done.
[PATIENT]: I’m trying to eat, but it’s hard.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay, Lily. We’ll support you through it. Just let me know if you feel unwell or overwhelmed.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s also on daily ECGs and electrolyte monitoring. Psych team has been consulted and will review again tomorrow. She’s been cooperative but very anxious.
[DOCTOR]: (enters briefly) Just confirming—Lily is for continued cardiac monitoring and nutritional support. Please escalate if HR drops below 35 or if she becomes symptomatic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue Q-ADDS, monitor intake, and keep an eye on her cardiac rhythm and electrolytes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, food chart, and med chart.

[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Jordan, 31 years old. Daniel, this is Alicia, one of our pharmacists. She’s here to talk to you about your new medication.
[PHARMACIST]: Hi Daniel, nice to meet you. I understand you’ve just been diagnosed with epilepsy.
[PATIENT]: Yeah… it’s a bit of a shock. I had a seizure yesterday, and they said it was my first one.
[NURSE]: He had a generalised tonic-clonic seizure yesterday morning. CT and EEG are pending, but neurology has started him on levetiracetam 500 mg BD. No IV access now—he’s on oral meds only. No known allergies.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. Daniel, I’ll go through how to take your medication, what side effects to watch for, and how to manage your day-to-day safely. Have you had a chance to read the medication leaflet?
[PATIENT]: Not yet. I’m still trying to take it all in.
[PHARMACIST]: That’s okay—we’ll take it step by step. Levetiracetam is taken twice a day, about 12 hours apart. It’s important not to miss doses. Some people feel a bit tired or moody when they first start, but that usually settles. If you feel very low or notice any big changes in mood, let us know straight away.
[NURSE]: He’s also on a food and fluid chart while we monitor his intake—he’s been a bit nauseous since yesterday but is improving.
[PHARMACIST]: Good to know. Daniel, you’ll also need to avoid driving for now—by law, you need to be seizure-free for a certain period before you can drive again. We’ll give you written information about that too.
[PATIENT]: Okay. I didn’t realise that.
[PHARMACIST]: Totally understandable. I’ll leave you with a medication info sheet and come back later to check if you have any questions. We’ll also make sure your GP and community pharmacy are updated when you’re discharged.
[NURSE]: Thanks, Alicia. I’ll keep monitoring his neuro obs and ensure he’s tolerating the meds. Daniel, just press the call bell if you feel unwell or have any questions.
[PATIENT]: Thanks both. I appreciate it.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Ken, could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Ken Harris.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ve checked your ID band as well. The cannular looks like it needs changed it has been in for 3 days.  

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ken came in with an arrhythmia. He had chest pain this morning an ECG was done and reviewed by the team. He was given anginine and morphine for the pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ken, how’s the chest pain now? what is it out of 10? 10 being really bad.
[PATIENT]: Its about a 2, It’s eased off a lot. Just a bit uncomfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep an eye on it. Let me know if it gets any worse.

[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you need before I head off, Ken?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Maya. I'll be back Ken to do some obs, soon.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Mr Meyer. I’m the day nurse, Priya. I’ll just get handover from Tom who’s been looking after you overnight, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Priya. This is a new admission in Room 5, Bed 3: Mr Steve Richard Meyer, 71, under Dr Dalianis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Mr Meyer, can I quickly confirm your identity on the wristband? And what name do you prefer to be called?
[PATIENT]: Richard is fine, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Richard was admitted with multiple cardiac issues. He’s not for surgery yet the team want some weight lost first before considering an operation. Observations have been stable on my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None reported. Comfortable at rest, and seems settled.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a food chart and I have made a referral to the dietitian. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll follow up dietetics for a time today.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs prompting with ADLs and benefits from reminders and some assistance with personal cares and meal setup.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: let us know when you want a shower and when you meal has arrived ring the buzzer. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Richard’s wife passed two months ago. He’s understandably low in mood. I recommend a pastoral care referral for grief support.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Richard, would you be okay for us to arrange someone from pastoral care or someone to talk with about support?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I’d appreciate that.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:I’ll place that referral this morning.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any lines or drains, special precautions, or allergies we should note?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No special lines or drains noted, and no new issues flagged on admission paperwork. Primary team is Cardiology under Dr Dalianis.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the  Plan for today is to continue routine obs, maintain food chart, follow up dietitian review, prompt and assist with ADLs, and place pastoral care referral. I’ll also update the team if there are any changes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all I can tell you for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Richard, is there anything you need right now before Tom heads off?
[PATIENT]: Maybe some help getting washed later and a cup of tea when I’m allowed.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Kelly, this is Sam, the incoming nurse who'll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Kelly. Is it okay if we do handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Kelly Diana Clarkson. 12 Jan 1990
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. And any allergies?
[PATIENT]: Pollen — I get hayfever.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Kelly is 36 years old, and is under Dr. Mills. She was admitted with query asthma for further investigation.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Natalia, are you feeling shivery or headachy right now?
[PATIENT]: I'm just hot and tired.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s been coughing up small amounts of blood and having some difficulty breathing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, has the coughing or breathlessness changed overnight?
[PATIENT]: No, about the same. Just little streaks when I cough.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise she’s self-caring and ambulant. No other changes—she’s still the same as yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any new meds or interventions overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new orders overnight aside from regular antipyretics as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, are you comfortable walking to the bathroom yourself, or would you like us to walk with you?
[PATIENT]: I can walk, but I’d like someone nearby because of the breathing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No problem, we’ll assist. Just ring me when you need to go to the toilet.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: What is the plan for Natalia?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Continue antipyretics as ordered, monitor fever and respiratory status. Escalate to the medical team if the haemoptysis increases or her breathing becomes worse.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep close eye on observations and let Dr. Cox’s team know of any changes.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, is there anything you need right now—water, fan, or a cool cloth?
[PATIENT]: A cool cloth would be nice.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll bring that straight in. Thanks, Mia.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is Bed 5, Sandra Murdock.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Sandra, I’m the incoming nurse. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No immediate concerns so far. She seems comfortable and resting.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The surgeons still need to review her today to decide on whether she need to have surgery.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: If they proceed, she needs to be nil by mouth tonight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll place NBM orders/signage for tonight if its confirmed.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you have Pain, or feeling more breathlessness, or anything we can get you now, Sandra?
[PATIENT]: I’m comfortable, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I think I have covered everything. She seems okay and is resting.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep an eye out for the surgical team and any updates from biopsy. Sandra, buzz if you need anything.

[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Coco. I’m Priya. We’ll do a quick bedside handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. This is bed three, Coco Constantino, 61 years old, under Dr. Hudgens. He came in with pneumonia and an allergic reaction to penicillin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Coco, can you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Coco Constantino.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—penicillin. He was accidentally prescribed penicillin for the pneumonia and developed a rash, fever, and difficulty breathing afterward. Allergy is now documented.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Noted—penicillin allergy with rash, fever, breathing difficulty.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Respiratory-wise, he’s on his regular puffers with PRN nebulisers. He’s also on prednisolone; we’re doing random BGLs. He’s on oral antibiotics and an antihistamine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I will do  BGL checks, and give oral ABs (non-penicillin), and antihistamine as ordered.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Today he’s afebrile. He’s on oxygen at 2 litres via nasal prongs. Sats are normal and all other obs are stable. He has a QADDS of 2 for breathing the doctors are aware.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Coco, how’s your breathing now?
[PATIENT]: Better than yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear. Any itch or rash still bothering you?
[PATIENT]: A bit of itch, but it’s settling.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The plan for today is to continue oxygen at 2 L and wean as tolerated, monitor sats and obs, continue puffers/PRN nebs, steroids with random BGLs, oral antibiotics and antihistamine. We’ll reinforce the penicillin allergy bracelet and chart.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay are you happy with the handover
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Coco, press the call bell if you feel short of breath or the rash worsens. I’ll be back to check your sugars and see if we can reduce the oxygen later.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Matthew, I’m just handing over to Evie for day shift.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Matthew David Dung. Date of birth is 28 September 1967
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Matthew. Any medication allergies?
[PATIENT]: Not that I’m aware of.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll double-check your chart as well.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Bed 4, Matthew David Dung, 63 years old, under Dr. McDonald.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He presented with headache, nausea, and pain on inhalation following a gas leakage exposure at home.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on regular paracetamol for pain and has PRN anti‑emetics charted.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations have remained stable, and there have been no other changes since admission so a QAADS of Zero.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV lines or special equipment in use?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. So the plan is continue regular paracetamol, anti‑emetics PRN, and ongoing obs?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Matthew, is there anything you need right now—water, comfort measures, a cool cloth?
[PATIENT]: Maybe an anti‑emetic soon, please.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Sure, I’ll bring that in shortly and recheck your obs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Matthew. I’ll leave you with Evie now.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is David Adams in bed 8, he is under Dr. Wu.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi David, I’m taking over your care now. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: David, could you confirm your name for us please, and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: David Adams. 16 January 1984
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, David. Any allergies recorded?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None recorded on the chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: David is 34, admitted with a head injury. He’s been having headaches and is photophobic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:  He’s on Endone and morphine for the pain, and is for a CT brain tomorrow, and depending on those results, they’re planning to do endoscopic brain surgery later this week.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay,  I’ll keep an eye on the schedule for CT.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for daily bloods but he is a difficult stab, you may need to get the phlebotomist to do them, he's on neuro obs QID as per orders.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have the bloods been taken today?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s pretty much self-caring and we’ve not noted any other issues.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: David, we’ll keep the lights a bit dim for your comfort with the photophobia and keep working on your pain relief. If your headache worsens or anything changes, please buzz.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan is to continue Endone/morphine for pain as charted, QID neuro obs, daily bloods, CT brain tomorrow, and wait for the surgical plan based on results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you want to add, David?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all good.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to do your next set of obs.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay. I’ll just check your ID band… Luke Keller, 74, under Dr. Lee. Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Gus. I’m Alex, the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Mia and then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Gus, I’m Mia from night shift. Is it okay if we do bedside handover with you?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Gus Milano, and 12 May 1951.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Gus. And you’re in bed two under Dr. Lee. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, this is Gus, who is 73 years old, admitted today with depression on the background of cancer. He’s just arrived and is still waiting for a psychiatry review, pastoral care, and for Dr. Lee’s team to come by.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so still needs a nursing admission and psych review. How have his observations been?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All stable since arrival QADDS of 1 for HR. He’s tolerating diet and fluids without any issues.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV lines or special precautions?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No special supports needed at present. 4 Houry observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications all up to date on the chart?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes the Chart’s in the file; the team will write it up when they see him.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Gus, how are you feeling right now—any nausea, pain, or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay physically.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for letting us know. Are you feeling safe here? If you have any thoughts of harming yourself or feel very distressed, please tell us straight away so we can help.
[PATIENT]: I will, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So the Plan for the morning is to continue routine obs, assist with meals as needed, and we’re awaiting psych, pastoral care, and the medical team review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye out for those teams and check back after rounds. Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mia.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Gus, your observations look good. I’ll be back shortly—use the call bell if you need anything or if your mood dips and you want to talk.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning, Taylor. This is Jerry Reed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Jerry.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jerry is 45, under Dr. Harry. He has a history of congestive cardiac failure, IHT, hypertension, type 2 diabetes (diet controlled), and depression.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with bilateral leg oedema. He has a right AV graft and is scheduled for haemodialysis tomorrow afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, he has a right AV graft in situ, and dialysis is tomorrow afternoon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a 1.2-litre fluid restriction with daily weights. He’s on IV furosemide. We also need lying and standing blood pressures to be done this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll do the blood pressure this afternoon. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for the diabetic educator tomorrow at 1 pm, and there’s a family meeting booked for Thursday at 2:30 pm.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, diabetic educator tomorrow 1300, family meeting Thursday 1430.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jerry’s been very demanding and at times aggressive with staff. We’ve been using clear communication and de-escalation; please approach with firm boundaries and escalate if safety is a concern.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s consistent with earlier. No other acute issues noted on my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll double-check your weight, input/output, and confirm your dialysis booking for tomorrow afternoon. I’ll also set reminders for the orthostatic BPs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. That’s everything from me.

[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Good Morning, Nicholas. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam, the night nurse. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Nicholas. So, this is Room 3, Bed 1: Nicholas Ferrer, 64, under Dr. Morris. Admitted with painful urination, haematuria, and reported fevers prior to admission.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Nicholas, could you tell us your full name, please, while I check your ID band?
[PATIENT]: Nicholas Ferrer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, matches the band. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes diet-controlled, depression, GORD, and gout.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations have been stable and he’s afebrile on the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain right now, Nicholas?
[PATIENT]: A bit of burning when I go, but otherwise okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll keep an eye on that and use what’s charted if you need it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We still need to collect a urine MCS, and he is for bloods tomorrow morning as per the request.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll make sure the urine specimen pot is at the bedside and labelled, and we’ll collect it next when you void. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still for the team review today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Under Dr. Morris so we’ll watch for their round.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's on a diabetic diet and his BGLs are BD as ordered.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any issues with intake?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is Eating and drinking fine and is self-caring and can mobilise independently.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. No falls risk concerns noted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, he’s steady.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Nicholas, the plan from here isto get a urine sample off to the lab, check your sugars twice today, and the medical team will review you. If the burning worsens or you notice more blood, please buzz us straight away.
[PATIENT]: Okay, will do.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Call bell’s within reach here—do you have it?
[PATIENT]: Yep, right here.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE] Nicholas, can I get you anything before we head off?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to set up the specimen and do your obs.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]:Good Morning. I’m taking over now, shall we do bedside handover?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Paulos, this is Maria. She’ll be your nurse today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hello, Mr Gomez Castillo. I’m Maria, your nurse. We’ll talk about your care now—okay?
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 2, This is Paulos Gomez Castillo, 74, under Dr Willow. He came in recently with renal colic—kidney stones—and has a long cardiac history noted in the file.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: He's got a complex cardiac history, I’ll review the notes after handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has multiple allergies—documented in the chart—and he’s wearing an allergy band.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I can see the red allergy band—thank you. 
[PATIENT]: Yes.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a soft, cut-up diet. Obs have been stable QADDS of zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: BP looks good at 110/80.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s VRE positive so he is on contact precautions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll make sure the family know how to put on PPE. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s waiting for  a chest X-ray and there is no confirmed time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep him ready for when they call for him.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on prophylactic Clexane, BD.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is today’s doses charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, they’re charted.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is NFR, but still for all regular meds and therapies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Not for resuscitation is the paperwork completed and in the chart?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, it is, He becomes intermittently confused and can be quite agitated at times.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is there anything that triggers him overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No its Mostly in the evening; he needs reorientation and a calm approach helped.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: he’s from a non‑English background but he understands some English. An Interpreter can be arranged if needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Paulos, if you need toilet or water, press the bell—okay?
[PATIENT]: Bell—okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The staff assist when walking, with a forearm support frame.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay We’ll use a gait belt as needed.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has an IDC in situ. Urine is being recorded on the fluid balance chart. His output has been low overnight so will need to be checked hourly. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check the catheter and continue fluid balance documentation.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No IVs currently.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain right now, Paulos?
[PATIENT]: Little… okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Small pain—okay, I’ll check your charted analgesia.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan for today is to maintain contact precautions; monitor obs; give Clexane BD; soft cut-up diet; staff‑assist mobilising with forearm frame; monitor confusion/agitation and reorient; keep ready for chest X‑ray; continue IDC care and fluid balance.
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need now, Paulos?
[PATIENT]: Water… small.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll bring some water and sit you up. Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Call me if you need anything else before I head off.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Edwin.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: When were they done.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: 1000 am this morning. The plan is that he will be discharged if results are negative; otherwise he’ll be treated as an outpatient. We’re still awaiting the team’s review and the go-ahead. Otherwise, he’s stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep an eye out for the results and page the team for review once they’re available.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. Edwin, once the doctors review your scans, we’ll let you know the outcome and next steps. If you’re cleared, we’ll arrange your discharge; if not, we’ll organise the outpatient plan.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you need anything before we go?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll hand over the pager to you. Thanks, Edwin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to update you when we hear from the team.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. I’ll take over from here—shall we do bedside handover for Bed 3?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sure. Hi Evan, this is Mia, she’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Evan. Can you tell me your name and age?
[PATIENT]: Evan Stephenson, 22.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Evan. We’ll chat while we check a few things.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Bed 3: Evan Stephenson, 22 years old. He came in after a fall and has rhabdomyolysis with acute kidney failure. He had very low blood pressure in ED and received a Gelofusine infusion stat. He’s more stable now, which is why he’s been transferred to the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s got an IDC in situ, and for strict fluid balance charting. IV fluids are running at 803 mL per hour as charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Just confirming—eight-zero-three per hour? I’ll double-check the order and the pump after handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, that’s correct per the current order.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on lying and standing blood pressures, daily weights, and daily bloods.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He appears swollen and bruised on the left side of his body. He’s for a review regarding his mobility. At the moment he’s resting in bed and currently stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Evan, any pain right now, or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Bit sore on the left side, but I’m okay lying still.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get your pain score shortly and make sure you’re comfortable.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Urine output’s being tracked on the fluid balance?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—IDC is patent and draining, the FBC is up to date.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check your IV fluids, review the orthostatic BP plan, and keep up with the daily weights and bloods. I’ll also follow up on the mobility review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. That’s everything from me.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Evan, is there anything you need right now before I check your pumps and observations?
[PATIENT]: Some water if I’m allowed?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll confirm your fluid orders and be right back. Use your call bell if you need anything.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Lars. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you now. I’m just going to get handover from Sam, the night nurse, at the bedside.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mia. This is Lars Wohler, 42 years old, Room 4, under Dr. Geller.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Lars, we’ll speak about you, and please jump in if you feel up to it.
[PATIENT]: (nods).
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with sepsis with a decreasing level of consciousness, on a background of chronic renal failure stage 4 on peritoneal dialysis. He’s had a full septic workup; results are pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Blood cultures sent?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, blood cultures were taken—awaiting results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s febrile—38.6—and we’ve started IV antibiotics. He’s also on IV fluids at 83 mL per hour.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The antibiotics are running and fluids 83 mL/hr. Any allergies documented?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None documented so far; unable to confirm with him given the reduced consciousness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is he nil by mouth?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—NBM due to decreased level of consciousness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Analgesia/antipyretics?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s written up for IV paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And code status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for full resuscitation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: PD?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His peritoneal dialysis regimen needs review—Dr. Geller will come later to review and advise.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Any other results back yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Nothing definitive yet; septic workup pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Lars, I’m going to keep you comfortable, we’ll keep your fluids and antibiotics going, and the doctor will be in to see you shortly. If you’re in pain, can you squeeze my hand?
[PATIENT]: (weak hand squeeze)
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. We’ll also keep you NBM until it’s safe.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check the line site, confirm the antibiotic timing, and chart the IV paracetamol. I’ll also keep an eye on temps and neuro checks, and wait for Dr. Geller’s review and culture results.
[PATIENT]: (nods)
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. I’ve got it from here.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Natalie. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Alex, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: That’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Natalie. So, this is room 4, bed 5. Patient is Natalie Caricas, 79 years old, under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She came in with stomach pain and jaundice. She has a Past history  which includes diabetes and obesity. She’s reporting feeling tired, a bit dizzy, and low in mood.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her urine has been very dark; I’ve sent a urine MCS. She arrived on the ward about three hours ago. Admission obs and paperwork are done, and her observations have been stable since arrival.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any mobility concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she needs assistance with walking. I’ve flagged that she should be referred to physio.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay so shes an assist with all mobilising and falls precautions in place.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: yes. Diet-wise she’s on a diabetic diet. We’re doing QID BGL monitoring, and she’s on oral hypoglycemics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: QID BGLs and oral hypos—no insulin charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No insulin charted at present.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pain management?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s charted for Endone and morphine PRN for pain. She’s been uncomfortable, so please assess and medicate as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Will do.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She hasn’t been seen by the medical team yet; she’s here for further investigation. We’re awaiting the team review under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Natalie, how are you feeling right now—any pain, dizziness, or nausea?
[PATIENT]: My belly still hurts, and I feel a bit light-headed. I’m also just… a bit down.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you for telling us. I’ll check your observations now, get you some pain relief if it’s due, and make sure you’re safe when you get up. We’ll also let the doctors know how you’re feeling when they come.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me: her obs are stable a urine MCS was sent, she's an assist with mobility, and is on adiabetic diet with QID BGLs, oral hypoglycemics, PRN Endone/morphine charted, awaiting team review and physio referral.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Natalie, your call bell is within reach—please ring before you get out of bed and we’ll come and help.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Sharma, I’d like you to review Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday with a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but showing significant right-sided weakness and difficulty with coordination.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[NURSE]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. Vitals are stable: BP: 142/86, HR: 78 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 2 for (BP + mobility). He’s mobilising with assistance but has poor upper limb function on the right. He’s struggling with feeding and grooming tasks. I think he’d benefit from an occupational therapy referral to assess for functional support and equipment.
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm—patent and flushed. No IV fluids running currently.
[DOCTOR]: What medications is he on?
[NURSE]; He’s currently prescribed: Aspirin 100 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Perindopril 4 mg daily, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN for comfort. No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: How is he positioned?
[NURSE]: We’re using 30-degree lateral tilt positioning to offload pressure areas and support his hemiplegic side. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll review him and put in the OT referral. Please continue neuro obs and let me know if his mobility or cognition changes.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll also update the allied health team and document the referral request.

[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Hi Dr. Patel, I’m handing over Mr. Anthony Reid, a 64-year-old patient who was admitted earlier today with a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). He’s being transferred to your unit for ongoing cardiac management and potential intervention.
[Receiving Doctor]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: He’s currently on: IV Heparin infusion – weight-based protocol, currently running at 1000 units/hr, IV GTN infusion – titrated to chest pain, currently at 10 mcg/min, Oxygen therapy – 4 L/min via nasal prongs, saturations are sitting around 89–91% on oxygen. He’s still reporting mild chest tightness but is hemodynamically stable.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any recent observations?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, latest obs: BP: 104/68, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 20, Temp: 36.8°C , SpO?: 91% on 4 L O?, Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to low SpO?, chest pain, and IV therapy)
[Receiving Doctor]: Any IV access?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, he has a 16G cannula in the left antecubital fossa and a 20G in the right forearm. Both are patent and flushed. GTN and heparin are running through separate lines.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any other medications?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]:
He’s also had: Aspirin 300 mg stat, Ticagrelor 180 mg stat, Atorvastatin 80 mg stat, Morphine 2.5 mg IV PRN – last dose was 2 hours age. No known drug allergies.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any investigations done?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, ECG confirmed anterior STEMI. Troponin is elevated. Chest X-ray shows mild pulmonary congestion. Bloods including FBC, U&E, and coagulation profile have been sent—awaiting results.
[Receiving Doctor]: Thanks. We’ll prepare for his arrival and continue cardiac monitoring. Please send through the medication chart and infusion protocols.
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Will do. I’ll also include his fluid balance chart and latest obs summary.
